title: 115_s943
content: The Act titled the "Johnson-O'Malley Supplemental Indian Education Program Modernization Act" updates the Indian Education Program by defining key terms such as contracting party, eligible entity, and existing contracting party. It aims to modernize the program and improve student count computation. The JOM Modernization Act defines key terms like JOM Modernization Act, new contracting party, and Secretary. The Act requires the Secretary to determine the number of eligible Indian students served by each eligible entity. The Secretary, in consultation with eligible entities, determines the number of eligible Indian students served by each entity using accurate data from the preceding fiscal year. The Secretary, in consultation with eligible entities, determines the number of eligible Indian students served by each entity using accurate data from the preceding fiscal year. To improve accuracy before publishing, the Secretary reconciles the data with each existing contracting party's data and identifiable tribal enrollment information. The Secretary establishes a 60-day comment period for feedback on the preliminary report from eligible entities. A final report on the number of eligible Indian students served by each entity is published within 120 days after consultation. Subsequent academic years require determinations for eligible students served by contracting parties. The Secretary determines the number of eligible Indian students served by contracting parties based on reported student count numbers. Contracting parties must submit a report on eligible students served and funds expended, failure to comply results in no funding. The Secretary shall provide contracting parties with timely information on reporting deadlines and consequences of non-compliance. Technical assistance and training will be provided to ensure compliance with reporting requirements. Additionally, an annual report will be prepared, including the number of eligible Indian students served, funding recommendations, and an assessment of contracts under the Act. The Secretary will provide funding recommendations for the program in the budget request, submit reports to specific committees, and make them publicly available. The report will be prepared to minimize administrative burdens on contracting parties. Hold harmless provisions will be implemented. The JOM Modernization Act imposes new administrative burdens on contracting parties receiving funds. Hold harmless provisions ensure existing parties do not receive less funding than the previous fiscal year, with exceptions under certain conditions. The JOM Modernization Act imposes new administrative burdens on contracting parties receiving funds, including consequences for failure to report, violations of contract or law, and decrease in student count. The JOM Modernization Act imposes consequences for funding reductions for existing contracting parties reporting decreased student counts, ensuring they do not receive less funding per eligible Indian student than the previous fiscal year. If funds are insufficient, the Secretary will ratably reduce amounts for all parties. This provision will sunset 4 years after the Act's enactment, with a maximum decrease in funding after that period. Beginning 4 years after the JOM Modernization Act's enactment, contracting parties cannot receive more than a 10 percent decrease in funding per eligible Indian student from the previous fiscal year. The Secretary may recommend legislation to increase funds per student to 1995 levels and explore additional funding sources without reallocating existing funds. Increases in program funding are subject to certain conditions. Increases in program funding under the JOM Modernization Act are allocated to contracting parties that did not receive their full per student funding allocation in the previous fiscal year. The excess amounts are first allocated to new contracting parties in need. After the first fiscal year of receiving full funding, this allocation process ends. The Secretary aims to increase geographical and tribal participation in the Johnson-O'Malley Supplementary Education Program by consulting with Indian tribes and educational agencies. The Secretary consults with Indian tribes, State and local educational agencies, and Alaska Native organizations to determine interest in entering contracts under the JOM Modernization Act. A rulemaking process will clarify eligibility requirements for contracting parties and revise the funding formula. The Secretary will clarify eligibility requirements and revise the funding formula for contracting parties under the JOM Modernization Act. A report will be submitted to Congress within 30 days of completing the rulemaking process. Data collection and reporting will protect the rights of eligible Indian students. The Comptroller General will review the implementation of the JOM Modernization Act, focusing on accuracy of student determinations, communication between the Bureau of Indian Education and contractors, and funding distribution. A report will be submitted to the Senate Committee on Indian Affairs and the Subcommittee on Interior, Environment. The JOM Modernization Act requires reports to be submitted to specific Senate and House committees and makes the report publicly available. The Act does not create new programs or duplicate existing ones, nor does it replace or diminish current regulations unless expressly stated.
